snippet: A Manhattan woman’s fatal plummet from her 17th-floor apartment on Thursday highlighted the risks that New Yorkers take when they venture on to their balconies.
abstract: Fatal fall of Jennifer Rosoff from 17th-floor Manhattan apartment highlights risks New Yorkers take when they venture out onto residential balconies; Buildings Dept is still investigating collapse of railing, but no foul play is suspected; order barring residents in Rosoff's building from using their balconies remains in effect and a $2,000 fine has been issued for failure to maintain the balcony, which was built in the 1930s.

byline.original: By CARA BUCKLEY and MONA EL-NAGGAR

lead_paragraph: A Manhattan woman’s fatal plummet from her 17th-floor apartment on Thursday highlighted the risks that New Yorkers take when they venture on to their balconies.

headline.seo: Fatal Fall Highlights Risk of New York Balconies
headline.main: A Place to Go Outside, but Not Look Down
headline.print_headline: Going Outside For Air, but Not Looking Down
